bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 46 (Thursday, March 15, 2018)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. GUTHRIE:H.R. 5306.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8[Page H1652]

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance.

item.text: Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by Voice Vote.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Forwarded by Subcommittee to Full Committee (Amended) by Voice Vote .
Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

item.title: H.R. 5306, Ensuring Medicaid Provides Opportunities for Widespread Equity, Resources, and Care Act

item.name: Department of Health and Human Services

item.text:
Ensuring Medicaid Provides Opportunities for Widespread Equity, Resources, and Care Act or the EMPOWER Care Act

This bill amends the Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 to extend funding through FY2022 for the Money Follows the Person Rebalancing Demonstration Program and to otherwise revise the program. (Under this program, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must award grants to state Medicaid programs to assist in rebalancing states' long-term care systems.)
item.name: Introduced in House

bill.title: EMPOWER Care Act

item.title: To reauthorize the Money Follows the Person Demonstration Program.
Ensuring Medicaid Provides Opportunities for Widespread Equity, Resources, and Care Act

latestAction.text: Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by Voice Vote.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
